value_name: presence of the marker in numerals 2—10
presence of the marker in numerals 2—10
comment: 1' and '2' omit the marker when used attributively. '40' jaxc’ur does not bear the marker, too. Other than that, all components lower than 100 have the marker. No info on millions.

value_name: presence of the marker in numerals 2—10
comment: Only after components 1—10, 20. Info on whether tens 30, 50, 60, … 90 inflect by class varies in sources. No info on millions.

value_name: presence of the marker in numerals 2—10
comment: Only after components 2—10, 20. No info on millions.

value_name: presence of the marker in numerals 2—10
comment: Full form -CM-le is used only after components 1—10 and 20 when they are final or when counting millions. Just -CM is used in final positions in 11—19, 21—29, and in non-final positions in 2—10 and 20.
example_comment: It seems that the class marker here is -d initially but it undergoes assimilation before /l/ and becomes -l. About assimilation: [alekseevetal1998: 398 (in the file)]

value_name: presence of the marker in numerals 2—10
comment: Class marker does not appear in the adnominal position (when substantivized, only after components 1—10, 20).

value_name: presence of the marker in numerals 2—10
comment: Class marker does not appear in the adnominal position (when substantivized, only after components 1—10, 20).

value_name: presence of the marker in numerals 2—10
comment: Only after components 1—10, 20 (100 is derived vigesimally, so it has the marker too). No info on millions.

comment: Only after components 1—10, 20 (100 is derived vigesimally, so it has the marker too). No info on millions.

presence of the marker in numerals 2—10
comment: In the substantivized form in numerals 1, 2, 3, and 5 the glottal stop is added after the root (all of which end with vowels). Root '4' ends with the glottal stop in all positions, it is a part of the root.
